name: benzenesulfonamide, 4-amino-n-(5,6-dimethoxy-4-p
Reason: The target compound benzenesulfonamide, 4-amino-N-(5,6-dimethoxy-4-pyrimidinyl), has several functional groups influencing its melting point. The basic benzene unit has a melting point of 5.5°C. The sulfonyl group attached to the benzene typically raises the melting point due to the introduction of strong dipole-dipole interactions and potential for hydrogen bonding, which we can approximate as a +110°C increase. The amino group on the benzene can create intermolecular hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point further by approximately +80°C. The pyrimidine ring is similar to benzene, so its direct contribution is minimal, but it does add to the molecular complexity, which we can estimate as a +10°C increase. The methoxy groups on the pyrimidine generally decrease melting point due to the electron-donating effects weakening intermolecular interactions; each methoxy might lower the melting point by about -10°C. Summing these adjustments gives us a predicted melting point.
Prediction: 5.5 (base benzene) + 110 (sulfonyl group) + 80 (amino group on benzene) + 10 (pyrimidine complexity) - 10 (first methoxy) - 10 (second methoxy) = 185.5°C
